Fig. 1 Catalytic performance (a) and stability (b, c) of CZ-MIL, CA-ZIF and C-ZAx [The bar chart shows product selectivity at 3 and 4 MPa (shadow marked), the scattered points stand for the CO2 conversion (red square for 3 MPa, blue for 4 MPa) and STYMeOH (purple asterisk for 3 MPa and blue for 4 MPa); Reaction conditions: 3 MPa, H2/CO2=3:1, 6000 h−1, 523 K]. Fig 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns (a, b) and H2-TPR profiles (c) of CZ-MIL, CA-ZIF and C-ZAx (a, c: before reaction without prereduction; b: after reaction). Fig 2 Fig. 3 HRTEM(d-f) and EDS-mapping images (a-c) of catalysts after reaction (a, d: CZ-MIL; b, e: C-ZA0.6; c, f: CA-ZIF). College of Environment and Ecology Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan Shanxi 030024 China 1 Represents co-first authors and contributed equally to this work. Acid-base synergistic effect is crucial in adjusting the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, an efficient CO2 emission reduction and carbon recycle strategy. Two MOFs-derived catalysts (CZ-MIL, CA-ZIF) with opposite acid-base properties were tailored by using MIL-68 (Al) and ZIF-8 (Zn) as precursors, and the above two MOFs precursors were hybridized (C-ZAx) to control the acid-base property of the catalyst. C-ZA0.6 (molar ratio of MIL-68 (Al) to ZIF-8 (Zn)=0.6) exhibits a promising catalytic performance with CO2 conversion of 8.9 %, methanol selectivity of 61.85 %, and STY of 117.02 mg mL−1·h−1 at 4 MPa and 523 K. Combined with comprehensive analysis, it is found that methanol selectivity is closely related to weak acid sites arising from the residual skeleton of MIL-68. Acid-base synergy facilitates the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. The basic sites are responsible for adsorbing and activating CO2, and the acidic site helps to stabilize CO* and facilitate the further hydrogenation to methanol. This work provides a new idea and feasible method for enhancing the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MOFs MIL-68 ZIF-8 CO2 Hydrogenation Methanol Acid-base synergy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Human activities will lead to massive emissions of CO2, which will cause the global average temperature rising by 2–4 K by the year of 2100, and a series of resultant global climate issues are bound to threaten the survival of human beings [1,2]. Thus, capturing and converting CO2 to value-added chemicals can not only realize CO2 reduction emission, but also drive the development of the chemical industry [3–6]. The down-stream products by utilizing CO2 as a feedstock in the chemical industry includes urea [7–9], methanol [10,11], carbonates [12–14], carboxylic acids [15], urethanes [16], esters [17], and lactones [18]. Thereinto methanol attracts extensive attention due to its versatility as a fuel, an ideal hydrogen storage material, or as a raw material for the synthesis of olefins and aromatics. Therefore conversion of CO2 to methanol has a wide market perspective [19,20], in which CuZnAl catalyst has attracted special attention due to its low cost and potential performance. But it still faces difficulties and challenges in unsatisfying CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity, as well as the unacceptable stability of catalysts due to the aggregation of active components. Besides, the reaction mechanism and the key factors in controlling the reaction is far from distinct. Although some researches have shown that the coexistence of acid-base sites is conducive to the improvement of methanol selectivity [21], the detailed mechanism of acid-base sites in the reaction is still not clear. With special porous structures and variable skeleton metal ions, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are widely used in CO2 hydrogenation reactions due to their abundant channels and high specific surface area [22], which is beneficial to the well-dispersion of the active components. Furthermore, it's tunable ligand types can also provide a variety of reactive sites and unique acid or base sites. In our previous work, ZIF-8(Zn) and MIL-88B(Fe) have been demonstrated to have superior ability to disperse active compositions and enhance the catalytic stability [23–25]. As potential precursors with two key active elements (Zn and Al) in CO2 conversion to methanol, ZIF-8 and MIL-68 are considered to have abundant porous structure and excellent hydrothermal stability [26]. Most importantly, with imidazole as ligand, ZIF-8 normally shows good CO2 capture capacity, which makes it feasible in activating CO2 [27,28]. Besides, CO is usually the main by-product of the reaction over CuZnAl-based catalysts [29]. Stabilization, activation and conversion of CO and the intermedium CO*, is a possible strategy to enhance the selectivity of methanol. Theoretically, acid sites benefit to the activation of CO, and MIL-68 could provide Lewis acid sites due to its characteristic skeleton structure. Therefore, two MOFs materials of ZIF-8 and MIL-68 were selected as precursors of active composition Zn and Al to produce a series of catalysts with adjustable acid-base properties. After loading with the other active compositions Cu and Al or Zn by impregnation and calcination, they were applied in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. We also proposed a possible mechanism based on In-situ DRIFTS. It is revealed that CO2 is hydrogenated to generate a certain amount of methanol through the formate pathway accompanied by reverse water gas shift reaction to produce the byproduct CO. Subsequently, CO will transfer to and be adsorbed at the acidic site to be further hydrogenated to methanol, thereby the selectivity of methanol will be improved. The present work could hopefully provide a feasible way to enhance the catalytic performance via tailoring acid-base property as well as a reasonable way for understanding the interaction mechanism of CO2 conversion to methanol. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and reagents Copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, 99 %), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, ≥99 %), aluminum nitrate nine-hydrate (Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O, ≥99 %), ammonia solution (NH3, 25–28 %) and absolute alcohol were purchased from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.; Aluminium chloride hexahydrate (AlCl3⋅6H2O), p-phthalic acid (PTA), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5 %) and 2-methylimidazole (98 %) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. All chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Distilled water was purchased from Taiyuan University of Technology Pilot Base (pH ≈ 7). Hydrogen (H2, ≥99.99 %), carbon dioxide (CO2, ≥99.99 %), argon (Ar, ≥99.99 %) and nitrogen (N2, ≥99.99 %) were purchased from Taiyuan Fujiang Special Gas Co., Ltd and used as they purchased. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis 2.2.1 Preparation of MIL-68 and ZIF-8 MIL-68(Al) was prepared typically by the following process (Fig. S1a). 7.5 g terephthalic acid (PTA) and 7.32 g AlCl3·6H2O were dissolved in 300 mL DMF, the mixture was placed in a round-bottom flask equipped with a condenser, after being heated at 403 K for 18 h, the resulting product was filtered and dried at 353 K for 12 h. The obtained solid was denoted as MIL-68 (Al). ZIF-8 was synthesized according to the following steps (Fig. S1b). Solution A was obtained by dissolving 22.3 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O in 110 mL distilled water; solution B was obtained by dissolving 12.3 g 2-methylimidazole in 110 mL ammonium hydroxide; then solution A was added directly to solution B with stirring at room temperature for 2 h, followed by filtration. The obtained solids were subsequently dried in a drying oven at 353 K for 12 h. 2.2.2 Preparation of catalyst CZ-MIL, CA-ZIF (Fig. S1c) MIL-68 was dispersed in a mixture of water and ethanol with a volume ratio of 1:1, then Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O were added to the above mixture with a molar ratio of Cu:Zn:Al=2:1:1.2 accompanied by stirring at 353 K for 2 h and ultrasonic treatment for 0.5 h. After repeating the vigorous stirring and ultrasonic treatment process, the solvent was evaporated at 353 K in drying oven for 24 h. Subsequently, the dried solid was ground into powder and calcinated at 553 K for 4 h in a tube furnace under a nitrogen atmosphere. At last, the catalyst powder was tableted, granulated and named as CZ-MIL. CA-ZIF was prepared according to the similar process. ZIF-8, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O were added to a mixed solution of water and ethanol (volume ratio of 1:1) with a similar ratio of Cu:Zn:Al=2:1:1.2 as discussed above. Stir the mixture at 353 K for 2 h, followed by solvent evaporation. The following treatment is the same as that for preparing CZ-MIL. The obtained catalyst was denoted as CA-ZIF. 2.2.3 Preparation of catalyst C-ZAx A certain amount of MIL-68 and ZIF-8 were dispersed together in 300 mL mixed solution of water and ethanol (volume ratio, 1:1) followed by adding a certain amount of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O in the above mixture, maintaining the molar ratio of Cu:Zn:Al = 2:1:x (x = 0.3, 0.6, 0.9, 1.2). After stirring at 353 K for 2 h, the mixture was treated ultrasonically for 0.5 h. Repeat the stirring and ultrasonic treatment again; the mixture was dried at 353 K for 24 h in the drying oven to evaporate the solvent, and then the obtained solid was ground into powder and calcined at 553 K for 4 h in tube furnace under nitrogen atmosphere. Subsequently, the catalyst powder was tableted, granulated and named as C-ZAx (Fig. S1d). All the catalysts were prepared by lamination and granulation (40∼60 mesh). 2.3 Catalyst reaction The CO2 hydrogenation reaction was performed in a customized stainless steel fixed-bed reactor (with an inner diameter of 8 mm) at the condition of 3 or 4 MPa and 523 K, with mixed gas of CO2 and H2 (V(CO2)/V(H2)= 1/3), and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 6000 h−1. Typically, a certain gram of catalyst with the volume of about 1 mL catalyst was loaded in the reactor with both sides filled with quartz wool to prevent the catalyst from blowing out. When the reaction approached stable, the products were analyzed online by GC-950 N gas chromatograph (Shanghai Haixin Chromatography Instrument Co., Ltd.). CO and CO2 were separated by a TDX-01 packed column and detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). While alcohols and hydrocarbons were separated by MAGE-624 and HP-PLOT/Q packed column, respectively and detected by flame ionization detector (FID). The CO2 conversion and product selectivity were calculated according to the following equations: C i = x i × L × p × 273.15 22.4 × 101.325 × ( 273.15 + T ) X C O 2 = ∑ ( n i × C i ) n ( C O 2 ) i n × 100 % n ( C O 2 ) i n = G H S V 1000 × 22.4 ∑ ( n i × C i ) = ( n C O × C C O ) + ( n C H 4 × C C H 4 ) + ( n C 2 H 6 × C C 2 H 6 ) + ( n C 3 H 8 × C C 3 H 8 ) + ( n C H 3 O H × C C H 3 O H ) S i = n i × C i ∑ ( n i × C i ) × 100 % STY = G H S V 1000 × 22.4 × V % ( C O 2 ) × X C O 2 × S C H 3 O H × M C H 3 O H Carbon balance = Σ n i n ( C O 2 ) i n − n ( C O 2 ) o u t × 100 % Carbon balance during the study ranged from 99.6 % to 100.0 %, confirming conservation of carbon mass throughout the reaction. Where C i is the mole number of a specific product i; x i is the measured mole fraction of product i in GC-950 N (mol/mol); L is the 24 hour cumulative exit gas volume (L); p is the daily atmospheric pressure (KPa); T is the laboratory temperature during measurements (℃); 22.4 is the molar volume of gases at STP (L/mol);101.325 is normal air (KPa);273.15 is thermodynamic temperature (K); X C O 2 is the conversion of CO2; n i represents the number of carbon atoms in a certain product i; n ( C O 2 ) i n stands for the mole number of CO2 at the inlet; GHSV is gaseous hourly space velocity; S i is the selectivity of a specific product i; V % ( C O 2 ) is the volume fraction of CO2 in the feed gas; S C H 3 O H is the selectivity of methanol; M C H 3 O H is the molecular weight of methanol; n ( C O 2 ) o u t stands for the mole number of CO2 at the exit. 2.4 Catalyst characterization H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurement was carried out on a chemisorption instrument (Tianjin Xianquan, TP-5000). Typically, 0.05 g catalysts were pretreated in helium flow at 423 K for 30 mins. After cooling to 323 K, helium was switched to the mixed reducing gas (5 % H2/N2) and swept for 30 mins. Then, the temperature was increased to 1073 K at a rate of 10 K⋅min−1 for the temperature-programmed reduction, and the hydrogen consumption was recorded by the thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of NH3 or CO2 was carried out on the similar chemisorption instrument for H2-TPR, the desorption gas was detected by mass spectrometry (QIC-20). Typically, about 0.05 g of the sample is first degassed in helium at 423 K for 1 h, and then exposed to an ammonia-nitrogen mixture (1 % NH3–99 % N2) or CO2 (99.99 %) for 30 mins after cooling down to 323 K. Subsequently, the gas was switched to helium to remove the physiosorbed NH3 or CO2 for 1 h. The signals were collected by TCD at the heating rate of 10 K⋅min−1 from 323 to 1023 K. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out on a Japan Smart Lab X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Corporation) equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ=0.15418 nm), with an operating current of 40 mA, voltage of 40 kV, the sample was scanned at a rate of 5 °∙min−1 in the range of 5–85 °. N2 physisorption and desorption analyses were performed on a QDS-30 physisorption apparatus (Kanta, USA). Typically, 0.15 g of catalyst was placed in a spherical sample tube, degassed at 473 K for 4 h, and then determined by N2 adsorption. The specific surface area was calculated by the BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) method, and the pore volume and pore diameter were assessed by the BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Hallnda) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger electron spectroscopy (XAES) were measured on a spectrometer with an Al-Kα X-ray resource (hν= 1486.6 eV) at the operating voltage of 12.5 kV and filament current of 16 mA. The results were corrected by C 1s at 284.8 eV. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) or In-situ DRIFTS spectroscopy characterization was performed on INVENIOS infrared spectrometer (Brook Company) at room temperature. For the normal FT-IR test, typically, a small amount of catalyst mixed with 0.1 g KBr and was ground and tableted for the test in a scanning range of 400–4000 cm−1. As for the in-situ characterization, the ground mixture of the catalyst and KBr was placed in an in-situ cell equipped with ZnSe windows. Samples were first pretreated at 523 K under Ar atmosphere for 30 mins at a flow rate of 30 mL min−1; after switching the gas stream to an H2/CO2 mixture (30 mL⋅min−1, H2/CO2=3:1), the signals were recorded at ambient pressure. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The effect of carrier precursor on catalytic performance As shown in Fig. 1 a, it is interesting that the CZ-MIL, with MIL-68 as carrier precursor, shows the optimal methanol selectivity and the lowest CO2 conversion. Meanwhile, CA-ZIF, with ZIF-8 as carrier precursor, shows the highest CO2 conversion and worst methanol selectivity. To achieve better catalytic performance, a certain molar ratio of MIL-68 and ZIF-8 were mixed as carrier precursor to load Cu species. It is notable that when keeping the amount of Cu and Zn constant and increasing the amount of Al (MIL-68), the methanol selectivity is enhanced, while the CO2 conversion shows an inverse tendency except for C-ZA1.2. Therefore, we could conclude that the carrier precursors play an important role in tailoring the catalytic performance. CA-ZIF (ZIF-8-derived) and CZ-MIL (MIL-68-derived) show completely different acid-base properties (Fig. 1 a), which causes different catalytic performance. CA-ZIF exhibits a higher CO2 conversion (11.70 %) rate, whereas CZ-MIL demonstrates a higher methanol selectivity (72.05 %). When the two MOFs carrier precursors are used simultaneously, an optimized catalytic performance is obtained. The methanol selectivity over C-ZAx series catalysts gradually rises with the increase of MIL-68 compared to CA-ZIF with ZIF-8 as the sole carrier precursor, thereby verifying the crucial role of the MIL-68 structure in enhancing the methanol selectivity (Fig. 1 a). In order to explore even better catalytic performance, the reaction pressure for catalysts C-ZA0.3, C-ZA0.6 and C-ZA0.9 was further elevated to 4 MPa while the reaction was carried out for some period of time (96 or 120 h) at 3 MPa. It is clear to see from Fig. 1 a that the CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity of the three catalysts are increased obviously after the pressure was increased to 4 MPa. The catalyst C-ZA0.6 achieves the optimum catalytic performance at 4 MPa with CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity of 8.90 % and 61.85 %, respectively. The stability data of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 b and c; all of the catalysts show good stability, which can keep stable for >120 h. Even when the pressure is promoted to 4 MPa, it remains stable. There is no obvious inactivation in the evaluated 120–192 h. 3.2 Catalyst chemical composition and microstructure In order to explore the real difference between CZ-MIL and CA-ZIF and the effect of the two MOFs precursors with different molar ratio on the composition, structure, as well as catalytic performance of the catalysts, multiple characterizations were carried out. In Fig. 2 a, it is demonstrated that we have successfully synthesized MIL-68 [30]. Fig. S2 shows the XRD patterns of the above-mentioned MOFs precursors and the simulated curves of standard species of ZIF-8; it is clear that the MOFs precursors were successfully synthesized. The chemical compositions of the catalysts before and after the reaction was shown in Fig. 2 a and b, it can be seen that ZnO (PDF No.99–0111), CuO (PDF No.89–5899), Cu2O (PDF No.78–2076), and Cu0 (PDF No.89–2838) species appear in each catalyst before the reaction. In the C-ZAx series of catalysts, with the increase of the proportion of MIL-68, the intensity of the diffraction peaks of Cu0 species gradually decreased. The intensity of the CuO phase diffraction peak gradually increased, which suggests that the addition of MIL-68 is beneficial to the close interaction between active compositions and the formation of high-valence Cu species. Besides, ZnAl2O4 presents in CA-ZIF before and after the reaction and in all the catalysts after reaction except for CZ-MIL (Fig. 2 a and b). It is notable that ZnAl2O4 appears in all the catalysts with ZIF-8 as precursors. Therefore, the formation of ZnAl2O4 in the catalyst may be related to ZIF-8. After the reaction, the Cu0 phase gradually gets weakened in the C-ZAx series of catalysts with the increase of the MIL-68 content (Fig. 2 b) similarly as that before reaction, further confirming that the introduction of MIL-68 contributes to the well dispersion and strong interaction of the active components. The characteristic diffraction peaks of MOFs precursor (MIL-68), appear in the XRD patterns of the CZ-MIL catalyst before and after the reaction, indicating that the MOFs porous structure is retained in the CZ-MIL, which validates the larger specific surface of the catalysts as suggested in N2 adsorption and desorption analysis (Table 1 and Fig. S3a-d). Among the C-ZAx series, only C-ZA1.2 (with the same Cu: Zn: Al ratio as CA-ZIF and CZ-MIL) exhibits the residual weak MIL-68 characteristic peaks, suggesting partial structural preservation (Fig. 2 a). That is because that the MIL-68 MOFs structure might break into fragments, or the amount of the residual complete MIL-68 structure of the catalyst after reaction might be below the detection limit of XRD due to the structure damage. Combined with the catalytic performance, this reveals that the structure of MIL-68 MOFs indeed works for methanol selectivity, even though the diffraction peaks are weakened compared to the original MIL-68. This could be further confirmed by comparing C-ZA1.2 with the CuZnAl catalyst (CZA) without the MOFs structure with the same Cu: Zn: Al ratio prepared by coprecipitation method. Moreover, the CZA (Fig. S4 and Table S1) shows a higher CO2 conversion (13.52 %), lower methanol selectivity (26.74 %) and lower methanol yield than CA-ZIF, indicating that the MIL-68 MOFs structure plays a crucial role in conversion of CO2 to methanol by regulating the acid-base property (Fig. S5). As shown in Fig. 2 c, the H2-TPR spectra support the above conclusion, too. The reduction peaks observed between 473–773 K (200–500 °C) correspond to the stepwise reduction of copper oxide species [31,32]. Notably, the high-temperature peak at 780 K (507 °C) likely originates from strongly interacted Cu species within the MIL-68 framework, as evidenced by the distinct complexity of CZ-MIL compared to CA-ZIF. This hypothesis is supported by HRTEM analysis (Fig. 3 a and c). As for the C-ZAx catalyst, the reduction peak temperature of copper species gradually shifts to a higher temperature region with the increase of loading amount of MIL-68, which suggests that the strong interaction between Cu and Al (MIL-68) species makes it difficult to be reduced to Cu0 during the reaction. This is consistent with the results of the XRD and HRTEM (Figs. 2 b and Fig. 3 b) results. The dispersion and interaction between active metals and carriers were studied by HRTEM and EDS-mapping for the representative catalysts CZ-MIL (with high methanol selectivity), CA-ZIF (with high CO2 conversion rate), and C-ZA0.6 (with excellent catalytic performance). Due to their excellent stability, the catalysts after the reaction were characterized and analyzed. From the TEM (Fig. 3 a-c) and EDS-mapping images of the catalysts, it can be seen that with the same reaction time, the catalysts exhibit different element distribution; all the elements except for Cu are even-distributed while the Cu atoms assemble to different extents in the order of C-ZA0.6>CA-ZIF>CZ-MIL according to the aggregation degree. This might owe to the porous MOFs structures of ZIF-8 and MIL-68. Obviously, Cu species are easily clustered with reactions carried out when employing mixed ZIF-8 and MIL-68 as carrier precursor. But even if the Cu particles get assembled, the catalysts still exhibit superior stability as shown in Fig. 1 b and c. It is notable that in CZ-MIL, C, N, O, Al atoms distribute well in a column and grey region (the rectangle frame selected area) as shown in Fig. 3 a, further confirming that the structure of MIL-68 is still preserved and Cu and Zn species are mainly attached to pores of MIL-68 in the form of nanoparticles (the gray part in the TEM image is MIL-68, and the darker area is Cu and Zn species). The higher methanol selectivity of the CZ-MIL and C-ZA0.6 catalysts may be related to the retention of the MIL-68 structure in the catalysts. HRTEM (Fig. 3 d-f) indicates that Cu0, Cu2O and ZnO are present in all of the activated catalysts, and ZnAl2O4 is observed in CA-ZIF and C-ZA0.6 catalysts except for CZ-MIL, which is consistent with the XRD results. The formation of ZnAl2O4 in C-ZA0.6 further confirms that the MIL-68 precursors been damaged partly because the fact that the only Al source is that in MIL-68 carrier. No Al species can be clearly seen in Fig. 3 d, suggesting Al species may exist in amorphous form. Besides, the abundant heterogeneous interfaces are observed in HRTEM images, which indicates that Cu, Zn, and Al ternary metals coexist and interact with each other to help to generates methanol during the reaction. The Cu-ZnO interface is capable of activating CO2 and H2 concurrently. ZnO can facilitate the adsorption and dissociation of CO2 and H2 via oxygen vacancy, while Cu can promote H2 relay [33–36]. The texture parameters of the catalyst before and after the reaction are shown in Fig. S3a-d and Table 1. Notably, the specific surface area is largest in CZ-MIL due to the preservation of MIL-68 structure, which is consistent with the XRD results. It becomes even larger after the reaction; this should be responsible for its highest acid site percentage (as discussed in 3.4) and optimal methanol selectivity. For the hybrid catalysts C-ZAx, it is interesting that the methanol selectivity shows the similar variation trend with the specific surface area and pore volume, which increase gradually with the MIL-68 dosage increasing. It is generally believed that a larger specific surface area is beneficial to the exposure of more active sites as well as he acid sites for the catalyst [37–39]. Otherwise, the CO2 conversion is less reliable on the specific surface area. The above result could be further testified by the N2O adsorption experiments. As shown in Table S2, when the MIL-68 dosage increases, the specific surface area of active composition Cu in the catalyst gradually increases testifying that the structure of MIL-68 itself is conducive to the increase of the specific surface area and the exposure of active compositions. Combined with the characterizations of H2-TPR and HRTEM, it could be deduced that the interaction between MIL-68 and Cu species is conducive to the dispersion of Cu species, resulting in an increase in the specific surface area of copper in the catalyst. 3.3 Effect of valence of Cu species in catalysts As discussed before, due to the promising stability of the catalysts, XPS characterization was performed on the catalysts after the reaction to explore practical active species. Fig. 4 a shows the XPS survey, obviously the characteristic spectra of Zn 2p, Cu 2p, Al 2p, N 1s , O 1s , C 1s can be detected in all the three catalysts, suggesting all the above elements present in the catalyst, which further confirms the XRD results. In the Cu 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 4 b), the Cu2+ satellite peaks are present in all of the catalysts without running under 4 MPa, which is consistent with the XRD results. It is interesting that the no satellite peak of Cu2+ could be detected in the catalysts evaluated under 4 MPa due to the fact that higher pressure is benefit to the reduction of Cu species. To further figure out the surface composition of the catalysts, Cu LMM spectra were deconvolved and the percentage of different Cu species were calculated according to the peak areas, as shown in Fig. 4 c and Table S3. Interestingly, the chemical compositions on the surface of CZ-MIL and CA-ZIF are much different. The percentages of Cu0 are similar, but the Cu+ and Cu2+ species dominate the surface of CA-ZIF and CZ-MIL, respectively. Because the reaction pressure affects the surface Cu species content greatly, more low-valent Cu species are detected after reacting under higher pressure. Therefore it is hard to compare them and relate them to the catalytic performance (as shown in Table S3 and S4), despite the valence state of Cu being reported to have a certain impact on methanol selectivity [40,41]. 3.4 Effect of basicity of the catalyst In order to discover the essential influencing factor of catalytic performance, the basicity of the catalysts was analyzed by deconvolving the O 1s [42], N 1s and Zn 2p XPS spectra because the decomposition of MOFs will disturb the CO2-TPD signals (Fig. S6) and notably the basicity of this series of catalysts primarily arises from the O atoms, N atoms and oxygen vacancy. The O 1s XPS peak can be deconvolved into three peaks, corresponding to weak base sites (∼532.5 eV), medium base sites (∼531.4 eV), and strong base sites (∼530.4 eV), respectively [43,44]. The percentage of a specific kind of base site is calculated according to the normalized peak areas and listed in Table 2 and Fig. 5 . Likewise, three fitted peaks of the N 1s spectra are shown in Fig. 5 c, the peaks near 398.5 eV and 400.5 eV are related to pyridine-like nitrogen and pyrrole-like nitrogen in the ligand of imidazole in ZIF-8, respectively, and no pyridine-like nitrogen are observed in CZ-MIL [45,46]. The peak at 399.3 eV is attributed to the metallic nitrogen species. Pyridine-like nitrogen can provide a Lewis base site [47], thereby improving the adsorption and activation of CO2. In addition, as shown in Fig 5 b, the XPS spectra of Zn LMM of all catalysts could be deconvoluted into two peaks similarly. The peaks around 986.3 and 989.8 eV are attributed to ZnO and ZnOx (0 < x < 1) [48], respectively, and the presence of ZnOx indicates that the partial reduction of ZnO helping to lose part of crystal lattice oxygen atoms and form defect sites. It is well known that oxygen vacancies or defect sites are conducive to CO2 activation. Linear regression was used to figure out the dependence of the factors related to the acidity of the catalysts, like the percentage of a specific type of base sites, pyridine-like nitrogen and oxygen vacancy on the CO2 conversion (as shown in Table S4), it is interesting to find that there is a perfect correlation between the CO2 conversion and the ratio of the total percentage of (strong base site + pyridine nitrogen + oxygen vacancy/defect site), indicating that strong base site, pyridine nitrogen as well as oxygen vacancy/defect site contribute to the activation of CO2. 3.5 Effect of the acidity of the catalyst The acidity of the catalysts was tested by NH3-TPD. Typically, the peaks in the range of 323–573 K, 573–800 K and 800–1073 K are ascribed to weak, medium, and strong acid centers, respectively. By comparing the NH3-TPD analysis of the catalysts with the CZA (Fig. S5) prepared by coprecipitation method, it is notable that the weak acid sites observed at about 419 K only appear in CZ-MIL owing to the residual structural features of MIL-68(Fig. 6 a and S5). This proves that the residual MOFs structure affects the acid property of the catalysts. Similarly, the percentage of a specific kind of acid sites are calculated according to the normalized area proportion. As shown in Fig. 6 a, it can be seen that weak acid sites increase with the CZ-MIL dosage increasing, and they become dominant in C-ZA0.9, where CZ-MIL has the maximum weak acid sites. The weak acid area has a specific linear relationship with methanol selectivity (R2=0.5174). It is interesting that with the same contents of Cu, Zn, Al for CA-ZIF, C-ZA1.2 and CZ-MIL, the number of acid sites are obvious different (peak area), which might be related to the formation of ZnAl2O4 and destruction of MIL-68 MOFs structure when ZIF-8 precursor is introduced in. This is consistent with the XRD and HRTEM characterizations. Combined with the catalytic performance, it is surprising to find that (as shown in Table 3 and Table S5) the proportion of weak acid sites is positively correlated with the selectivity of methanol with the goodness of fit R2 of 0.9122, proving that the relative amount of weak acid sites possibly accounts for their outstanding methanol selectivity because the weak sites can stabilize the intermedium CO* and promote it to further hydrogenate to produce methanol. This can be further supported by the FTIR spectra of the catalysts shown in Fig. 6 b. The broad band at 3446 cm−1 is due to OH stretching vibration in free water [49,50]. In both CA-ZIF and C-ZAx, the bands at 1631 cm−1 can be attributed to the vibration of CN of imidazole suggesting that the ligand of ZIF is retained in the catalyst. The bands appearing in CZ-MIL at 477 and 602 cm−1 are attributed to the vibration of the Al-O metal center [51], the unsaturated Al might be the source of acid property. The bands at 1416 and 1603 cm−1 belong to the stretching vibration (OC-O) of carboxylates, which are derived from the terephthalic acid coordinated with Al3+ [52]. The bands located at 1384 and 1441 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the C C bond of the benzene ring, indicating MOFs structure is reserved in CZ-MIL [51]. These bands, associated with the ZnAl2O4 structure, are observed at 677 cm−1 and 555 cm−1, and the as-detected bands are related to the vibrational modes of the Al-O and O-Al-O [53–55], respectively. Indicating that the introduction of ZIF-8 in C-ZAx destroys part of the MOFs structure of MIL-68, which might be the reason for the decrease in the number of acidic sites. 3.6 Synergistic effect of acid and base property Usually, CO can be adsorbed and activated over acidic catalysts; herein, in order to verify if the produced byproduct CO or CO* can be further hydrogenated and converted into methanol over CZ-MIL with abundant acid sites, another two strategies are introduced in addition to the MOFs hybrid catalyst C-ZA1.2 (keep the constant ratio of Cu: Zn: Al). One is grounding and mixing the two typical catalysts, CA-ZIF and CZ-MIL with the mass ratio of 1 (denoted as CA-ZIF@CZ-MIL) for this reaction. The other is use CA-ZIF and CZ-MIL as tandem catalyst, named as CA-ZIF/CZ-MIL, with CA-ZIF close to inlet and CZ-MIL near outlet. Both of the two catalysts are evaluated at 523 K and 3 MPa and their activity data are shown in Fig. 7 and Table S6, where CO2 conversion and STY of methanol are significantly enhanced in all of them in comparison with CZ-MIL and the comprehensive performance gets promoted especially for CA-ZIF/CZ-MIL. This might be because that CA-ZIF, with the strongest basicity can adsorb and activate CO2 efficiently, which not only can facilitate the conversion of CO2 but also is conducive to generating a large amount of CO*. Subsequently, the produced CO* will be transferred to and stabilized on a large number of weak acid sites in CZ-MIL, so that the further hydrogenation will take place easily and methanol will be generated subsequently. Obviously, the acid-base synergy plays an important role in the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Otherwise, the physimix catalyst CA-ZIF@CZ-MIL exhibits the superior methanol selectivity and worse conversion than the tandem catalyst suggesting the close contact of two typical catalysts is benefit to the conversion of CO or CO* to methanol, but the close contact the active compositions will lead to acid base neutralization, which is not conducive to the conversion of CO2. This further confirms the conclusion that the synergistic effect of acid and base sites is crucial for the synthesis of methanol. 4 Reaction mechanism To identify the key intermediates in selective hydrogenation of CO2 to CH3OH, In-situ DRIFTS spectra were carried out on C-ZA0.6 catalysts after exposure to a mixed gas of CO2 and H2 (the total flow rate is 30 mL/min, V(H2: V(CO2) = 3:1) as shown in Fig. 8 . Fig. 8 b-d provide magnified images of the color-coded zones (red, blue, green) indicated in Fig. 8, showing detailed structural features of each region. The peaks at around 2200∼2400 cm−1 belong to the asymmetric stretching vibration of adsorbed CO2 which present at 1 min and get stronger gradually. The bands at 1438, 1478, 1510, 2696 cm−1 correspond to CO3*, which also get intensified gradually (Fig. 8 a–c). Notably, bicarbonate HCO3* (1641, 1655 cm−1) and formate species HCOO* (1347, 1389, 1558, 2768, 2853, 2936 cm−1) were observed at 4 min. HCOO* gets intensified over time. CO3* species follow the variation trend of increasing initially and decreasing subsequently, indicating the gradual conversion of bicarbonate intermediates. About 5 min later, the presence of HCOOH (1752 cm−1) and CH3O* (1712, 2788, 2896, 2921 cm−1), indicating the further hydrogenation of adsorbed HCOO*. Obviously, HCOO* is a key intermediate for the conversion of CO2 to methanol, indicating that the catalyst primarily follows the formate pathway. In Fig. 8 d, no adsorbed gaseous CO was detected at typical positions of 2046 and 2143 cm−1, which may be due to the weak adsorption of CO leading to rapid diffusion and formation of the primary gas byproduct CO. This suggests that CO might mainly arise from the RWGS reaction, and the catalyst itself has a very weak adsorption and activation capacity for CO (as can also be confirmed by the CO-TPD in (Fig. S6b). Whereas the weak band at 1955 cm−1 is attributed to the adsorption of activated intermediate CO*, which could be adsorbed and activated at acidic sites, leading to the formation of HCO* (2738, 3024 cm−1). After further hydrogenation, peaks related to CH3O* species appear at 2788cm−1, which will subsequently be hydrogenated to produce methanol. To dig out the difference in the mechanism over C-ZA0.6, CZ-MIL, CA-ZIF, the comparison of their in-situ DRIFTS characterization was carried out and shown in Fig. S7. It can be clearly observed that there are significant differences in the peaks of HCOO* (at 2853 cm−1) and CH3O* (at 2921 cm−1), the intensity of theses peaks over them is in the sequence of C-ZA0.6>CA-ZIF>CZ-MIL, which follows the same sequence with their methanol yield as shown in Table S1. They are remarkable in C-ZA0.6 than CA-ZIF, suggesting the significance of acid -base synergism for synthesis of methanol. It is worth noting that the peak at 1955 cm−1, ascribed to CO*, over CZ-MIL is stronger than that over the other two catalysts, further confirming that acid sites are responsible for the activation of CO to CO*. Additionally, peaks of the adsorbed gaseous CO (at 2122 cm−1) could be observed at 20 min over CA-ZIF and it disappear at 60 min because that they might desorb from the catalyst surface without further activation and conversion. While it is obvious at both 20 min and 60 min over CZ-MIL catalysts indicating the appropriate acid sites are conducive to the adsorption of CO. In addition, the adsorbed gaseous CO can hardly be seen and very weak CO* could be observed in C-ZA0.6 indicating that suitable acid-base sites can quickly activate CO to CO* followed by hydrogenation to produce HCOO*, CH3O* and CH3OH. In summary, the importance of acid-base coordination in methanol generation is further proved. Fig. 9 shows the mechanism of hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol over CuZnAl catalyst. The Cu species is responsible for the activation and dissociation of H2 to form H*. CO2 is adsorbed and activated at the base site (medium, strong base sites, and Pyridinic-N) or defective sites on the catalyst surface and further hydrogenated with H* to generate HCOO*, which will be further hydrogenated to form H2COO* and subsequently H2CO*, H3CO* and finally to methanol. At the same time, CO* will be produced over strong base sites, and a certain amount of CO* will desorb from the surface of the catalysts to from the CO byproduct. But if with suitable weak acid sites like unsaturated Al in MIL skeleton, CO* will be stabilized and further combined with transferred H* to from HCO*, H2CO*, H3CO* step by step and eventually to methanol. Herein, CO* hydrogenation is a rate limited step. This is why CO dominates the products. 5 Conclusions In the present work, two typical catalysts CZ-MIL and CA-ZIF were prepared by using MOFs materials MIL-68 or ZIF-8 as catalyst precursors, and three strategies (hybrid, physimix and tandem catalysts) were adopted to evaluate the synergistic effect of acid and base sites. Simultaneously, acid site number was regulated by increasing the dosage of MIL-68 in the hybrid catalyst C-ZAx. The CO2 hydrogenation activity of these catalysts was evaluated at 523 K and 3 and 4 MPa. C-ZA0.6 exhibits the promising catalytic performance with CO2 conversion of 8.9 %, methanol selectivity and STY of 61.85 % and 117.02 mg mL−1·h−1 at 4 MPa. Through comprehensive analysis, it is found that the percentage of the weak acid site is in a good positive linear relationship with methanol selectivity. Basicity might arise from different ways, O atoms of the catalysts, pyridine-like nitrogen and oxygen vacancy/defects of ZnO, which is responsible for the stabilization and activation of CO2. The synergistic effect of acid and base sites is crucial for the synthesis of methanol. This work proposes new insights for understanding the CO2 hydrogenation reaction and puts forward a new idea in tailoring the acid and base properties of the catalyst, hopefully contributes to the improvement of the catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: Acid-base synergistic effect is crucial in adjusting the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, an efficient CO2 emission reduction and carbon recycle strategy. Two MOFs-derived catalysts (CZ-MIL, CA-ZIF) with opposite acid-base properties were tailored by using MIL-68 (Al) and ZIF-8 (Zn) as precursors, and the above two MOFs precursors were hybridized (C-ZAx) to control the acid-base property of the catalyst. C-ZA0.6 (molar ratio of MIL-68 (Al) to ZIF-8 (Zn)=0.6) exhibits a promising catalytic performance with CO2 conversion of 8.9 %, methanol selectivity of 61.85 %, and STY of 117.02 mg mL−1·h−1 at 4 MPa and 523 K. Combined with comprehensive analysis, it is found that methanol selectivity is closely related to weak acid sites arising from the residual skeleton of MIL-68. Acid-base synergy facilitates the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. The basic sites are responsible for adsorbing and activating CO2, and the acidic site helps to stabilize CO* and facilitate the further hydrogenation to methanol. This work provides a new idea and feasible method for enhancing the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol.
